author: redblade79
body:
It’s all about learning man! The fact you are cognizant of this means you’ll do well. I can give you so many examples of people our age who don’t even know what a 401k is. 

This one girl I work with is about your age and one day we started talking about 401ks and she said that she wasn’t contributing anything - not even the minimum to get a match. I asked why and she said it was because she couldn’t afford it. That would be understandable except she took not 1 but 2 trips around the world last year. I think she went to Morocco and then to Indonesia on the other trip. Oh and she’s going to the Caribbean in a few weeks for another trip. 

The point is that there’s a lot of idiots out there and just because you lost money doesn’t make you one. You are leaps and bounds ahead of your colleagues bro.

author: TrenAndOptions
body: Told you idiots to sell RKT before earnings. Why aren't any of you cognizant that the run up before earnings is pricing in good results? Yeah you may have the 1 or 2 that run up before earrings and still shoot up after earnings, but that's really rare.

author: _hi_
body:
It works, but you have to be sure you're disciplined enough to not start moving your stops, or taking on more size etc.   


Basically do not average into positions unless you already know at what levels you want to partake in, and at what point you're thesis is wrong.   


You'll keep convincing yourself that it's just extending a bit further than you initially thought, so if you just slightly adjust a stop.... you get the point. It snowballs and the more you fucking lose money and discipline the more you want to double down on the exact same trap that got you there in the first place.   


Sometimes you'll get lucky and think to yourself, whew that was a close one. It only takes that one time for you to not be lucky and game fucking over.   


Blew up 20k in 2017 back when that amount was still soul crushing to me. Had to stop trading for a while after that. 3 years later I've made up those loses and then some, but that lesson stuck. I still find myself sliding into that trap, but at least now I'm cognizant of the risks.

author: LoveBackwardsIsEvil
body:
Q1 2021 revenue guidance is also down from this quarter. The big trend all investors (for both Canada and US) should be cognizant of is the effect of price compression on top line revenues. 

Aurora is selling a lot more cannabis, but decrease in sales price is weighing down revenues. 

> Consumer cannabis net revenue1 was $35.3 million, a decrease of 9% over the previous quarter. **Total volume of dried consumer cannabis sold increased by 36%, but was offset by a 30% decrease in the average net selling price per gram** of consumer cannabis1 as the Company's value segment brand, Daily Special, accounted for a greater percentage of consumer cannabis net revenue, at 62% of flower revenue compared to 35% in the prior quarter. Consumer cannabis extract net revenue decreased by $1.5 million as compared to the prior quarter driven primarily by a loss of market share for vaporizer products.

Overall, this is another ugly "progress" quarter from a company that was on the brink of distress. Looks like they will make it in the long run, but I can't help but think these guys will merge with TLRY/APHA/CRON.

author: jsboutin
body:
I kinda agree with you. I actually think society is too mad too often and that's why we are having so many public problems today.

While it's great that people are cognizant of what's going on in the world and can articulate an opinion, it's really not healthy to feel outrage on a daily basis.

author: WestWorld_
body: Cognizant*

author: Moostucky_Stank
body: This half Martian half gremlin has cost me so much damn money over the years. Sell NVAX! They don’t make any money!  Don’t buy Cognizant!  Buy Satyam!  But Motient Technologies!  This cueball batboy wannabe shouldn’t be calling anyone crazy.

author: Cicero1982
body: I’m happier than a tornado in a trailer park! I picked out some value growth stocks last night, assessed the value I wanted to enter, and set my alerts. About an hour after market opened my alerts all blew up. I bought in on many, averaged down on a few, and ended today green. I have $12,000 allocated to averaging down on current positions if necessary and nearly 1/3rd of my portfolio available for new positions. Today was awesome! I now own SUM, CTXS, NET, IMOS, SIMO, & IVC. Even took a small position of DFFN for a short squeeze and very small position in BKYI because ... well ... freaking because!

author: sylvikhan
body: Nanox (NNOX) is also a good theranos candidate. I work in xray equipment and have been watching this company for months because their claims of a 10k CT system are bogus. (As is their xray source technology). It IPOed one or two weeks ago and their stock shot up to 3B valuation. Now finally some research firm (Citrix) called them out on their shit early this week, calling them theranos 2.0.

author: MustWarn0thers
body:
Cloud data storage. Wow Holy shit guys can you believe it?! It's not like hard drives. It's hard drives that are on servers and you store it there, hence the cloud!

It's nothing like iCloud or AWS or Drive or pure storage or  Google drive or Egnyte or Citrix collab or Dropbox business.

It's totally revolutionary.

author: Cicero1982
body: Same here. I bought and averaged down SUM, INTC, SIMO, CTXS, IVC, IMOS, NET, and got a 5% squeeze out of DFFN and BKYI. Green Day for me due to averaging down. This is why number 9 [HERE](https://www.reddit.com/r/pennystocks/comments/hcja2q/the_ultimate_quick_resource_for_the_amateur_trader/) is such a very strong and successful strategy, even amid temporary pullbacks. I can’t recommend it enough. It’s like getting penny stock-ish gains without the stress of pennies.

body: Guys take a look at CTXS

author: TG_Pro_Triathlete
body: 150 billion company, price to sales 90+, what could go wrong... Just think, the entire company of Citrix (go-to-meeting plus many other software products) is like less than 15 billion.

author: SoloTheFord
body:
On another note I think you have some solid picks; added some of those to my watchlists, Citrix is an interesting one. I was checking it out earlier last month. 

I took some AMD and NVDA stock a while back no regrets. I like the idea of investing on the innovators and future tech for my mains. TSLA comes to mind but its really hyped, i think it is overvalued right now even though I like what the company is doing. Opted for some AAPL instead.

author: KneeGrowsToes
body:
BB is representative of Canada as our top cyber security work and we are respected by many other countries, not just the US. The difference between CRWD and BB is the latter does not go after small fry. 


https://www.blackberry.com/us/en/company/newsroom/press-releases/2020/the-united-states-air-force-chooses-blackberry-spark-for-secure-productivity

When the entire world had to go remote overnight, many companies didn’t anticipate the massive surge of hacking attempts that occurred from all over the world. All it takes is someone who knows how to do it over Discord, and that person shows the next. It’s like virtual COVID. That expensive lesson is going be paid for when they realize ransom is a real threat in this world.

There’s a reason 9/10 major Canadian banks use them.

I am holding 10c and 20c for Jan 21. I want to profit as much as possible if this breaks out and is valued correctly. People still think they make phones. Even though they are releasing 5G phones from an American Manufacturer next year, it’s a drop in the bucket compared to QNX licensing and Spark UEM registrations. 18 of 20 G20 countries use Spark and they are the only product on DoD Approved Product List (and said by them the only product WORTH being on the list). I think this stock is gonna surpass CRWD in share price and Mkt cap soon. It’s been rebranded and updated as Spark UEM. They just hired Tom Eacobacci as President in June after he lead sales for Citrix for over 20 years and he gets to crank start the sales engine exactly how he wants. BlackBerry trades at 2-3x sales when CRWD trades at 30x. I am very confident they are gonna hit a massive beat Thursday BMO.

The purchase of Cylance was for a steal if you count the number of cyber security professionals they got with it. The demand for that talent during this pandemic was sky high and BlackBerry has the cash to pay them. With a centralized company, they only need one legal team, one accounting team. 
BB is representative of Canada as our top cyber security work and we are respected by many other countries, not just the US. The difference between CRWD and BB is the latter does not go after small fry.

author: EightFolding
body:
My top performers are: AAPL, FB, MSFT, MU, ACA, VWSYF, CTXS, TRN, MRVL, INO, CSCO, DOX, SNY, ABB. All with total gains over 40%. Those are *not* my recommendations, just my top performing holdings.

I'm self taught and ignorant about a lot, but try to learn. But I do have an investing philosophy. One of the big investing mistakes I think we all make is believing that how things are now is how they will always be, so I try to buy for a better future. And along with fundamentals I buy what I believe in, and what I've seen and used.

I do socially responsible self-directed investing. So I try not to buy anything that makes money directly from fossil fuels, war, harming people or animals,, prisons, poor treatment of immigrants, refugees, or asylum seekers, or, predatory financial industries, or any other industries that cause people, animals, or the environment harm. I think there's a fair argument to make that I'm breaking this rule to include tech companies like Facebook and some biotech, so that's my failure to work on. But my investments since the early 2000s have beat all the markets, and all the funds, just by choosing to have principles and trying to invest in companies that do good.

I also own other green energy, tech, grocery, railroads, data/commercial real estate, biotech. In the early 2000s I bought the companies that have become big tech, right now I'm buying transportation, biotech, 5G, AR, VR, and green energy companies along with companies I think will do well during the upcoming COVID-19 repeat. Despite the awful world we live in, I believe a better future is possible.

They just hired Tom Eacobacci as President in June after he lead sales for Citrix for over 20 years and he gets to crank start the sales engine exactly how he wants. BlackBerry trades at 2-3x sales when CRWD trades at 30x. I am very confident they are gonna get a massive beat Thursday BMO.

author: totsnotbiased
body:
The first thing I would do is double your interest in every ETF/ actively managed funds you own outside the S&P 500, and sell the small positions you have in low growth companies like J&J, JPM, KO, CTXS. 

A good rule of thumb for you might be if you can’t see a world where the stock could double in the next 12-24 months, you shouldn’t hold less than .5% of your total portfolio in it.

You’re highly diversified, but that’s what ETF’s are for, and they are probably better at it than any of us

author: Cicero1982
body: NET, CTXS, IVC, IMOS, SUM, SIMO. All value companies, all have great potential for growth, all hopefully will dip more today so I can pick up more shares and average down.

author: Cicero1982
body: I’m happier than a tornado in a trailer park! I picked out some value growth stocks last night, assessed the value I wanted to enter, and set my alerts. About an hour after market opened my alerts all blew up. I bought in on many, averaged down on a few, and ended today green. I have $12,000 allocated to averaging down on current positions if necessary and nearly 1/3rd of my portfolio available for new positions. Today was awesome! I now own SUM, CTXS, NET, IMOS, SIMO, & IVC. Even took a small position of DFFN for a short squeeze and very small position in BKYI because ... well ... freaking because!

author: bshaman1993
body: Guys take a look at CTXS

author: Trueslyforaniceguy
body: Yes!  Citrix, DOCU, WORK, PD

author: totsnotbiased
body:
The first thing I would do is double your interest in every ETF/ actively managed funds you own outside the S&P 500, and sell the small positions you have in low growth companies like J&J, JPM, KO, CTXS. 

A good rule of thumb for you might be if you can’t see a world where the stock could double in the next 12-24 months, you shouldn’t hold less than .5% of your total portfolio in it.

You’re highly diversified, but that’s what ETF’s are for, and they are probably better at it than any of us
